utterances: And many of these cases, as we have seen with this case involving Genarlow, it involves going beyond all the evidence that's before you.
And in this case, we're seeing the minority accusing the majority of going beyond what the general assembly intended.
But sometimes I think you need go beyond the bench as you look at these cases.
And I think in this case the Supreme Court may have done just that.
Now, I'm going to stay with you, John, different topic.
Back to SCHIP round two.
The president vetoed the bill earlier this month claimed expanding the program will allow for middle-income families to take advantage of the system.
This seems to have legs.
How do you think the story has been covered?
Is it something that's now playing out on a broader level nationally?
This - it's gotten a huge amount of coverage throughout the country.
And I think, you know - what I think to some extent is lost in all of this coverage.
A lot of coverage we've been seeing has been looking at who's winning and who's losing.
Whether the Republicans are head on this issue or can use this next year or the Democrat's can.
I think what's being lost here is the fact that we have millions of low-income people who actually need this insurance, who are not going to be able to get in that.

And I think a lot of the coverage we have seen have not really been zero in on that key fact, instead we're looking in effect who's up and who's down and who can use this issue, and I think that's unfortunate.
Dani, do you think this is playing out more on a level of - okay, what's this about or politics?

I think that's, yeah, I think that a lot of the coverage has focused on the politics and especially with the move of Dianne Feinstein coming through is, you know, a Democrat who've kind of crossed over.

But I think, you know, again, here in Wisconsin the focus has been - it's not really playing as that bigger story, I think, because we do have a pretty extensive, you know, SCHIP program here batch or care which was just expanded to include families above to 300 percent of the federal poverty level.
So the -our program here in Wisconsin was expanded and our budget just finally passed after months of deadlock on Tuesday.

And so I think most focus here are focused more on - that there's broad support for an expanded program and just many people are just taking kind of a wait and see approach to what's happening on the federal level.
And Adrian, these issues are very different locally.
Massachusetts has had a broad ranging set of health care initiatives.
Does that affect in Boston - at the Boston Globe?
How you cover the story?
I think it does a little bit.
You know, we're in the early stages of trying to or, you know, Massachusetts in the early stages of trying to insure everybody in the state.
And I think they probably makes SCHIP a little more interesting than it would be otherwise.
And I also agree with rest of the panel that it has been covered primarily as a political story as opposed to, you know, more substantively.
And I think that's too bad.
Well, you know, there's been, of course, this huge coverage of the wildfires.
There have been yoga and massages at San Diego's Qualcomm Center California's in flames.
And there has been a discussion, Adrian, of whether or not there is some shadow of Katrina.
Whether it's, oh wow, government has finally gotten its act together or hey, if you're white and you're not poor, you can get much better service.
Have you written about this?
How have people - other people, in your opinion, written about this?
I have not written about this and we haven't covered the wildfires extensively, I guess, because they're so far away.
But, you know, I think the Katrina comparisons are inevitable and you're going to see them every time there's a disaster like this.
And it is certainly interesting to see the contrast between the way they have responded, you know, relatively quickly in San Diego versus what we saw in Louisiana a few years ago.
Dani, what do you think about even making this comparison?
I think it's a fair comparison and I think it is inevitable.

I think that the way it's playing here in our editorial pages is, you know, clearly, the federal government and the coordination between various levels of government is working much better in California and isn't it sad that we had to kind of go through the horrors of Katrina in order for government to get its act together.
And that's been kind of consistent with what I've seen in the coverage elsewhere.

I think that - yeah, I think it's a fair comparison, I think that - I mean, again inevitable, maybe not fair, but I think that after what happened in '05, what we have to look at these types of disasters through that lenses, how poorly it was handled in Louisiana and the Gulf Coast.

John, is a disaster of huge magnitude, thousands and thousands of homes destroyed, so many people displaced, can you, as a reporter, make a judgment about whether a story that is localized, in this case, in California all the way across from where you are in Miami, should be heavily covered in your paper?
Well, Farai, I live in a state that - where we're no strangers to natural disasters with our hurricanes.
And so we can certainly empathize with what our friends in the - in some cases probably in California what they are going through.
So I think we have had it here at the Miami Herald on the front page several times although we are at the point where we're turning the corner on it because, to some extent, it's seems to be waning.
And going back to one of your earlier questions about whether or not we need to look at this to some extent through the Katrina lens, I think it's an appropriate question.
And even the president is addressing that given how we have - how the U.S.
government has handled Katrina, I think everything that comes after it, to some extent, has to be looked at through the Katrina eyes, and hopefully everyone can say, we'll never do that again.
Well, John, Dani, Adrian, thanks so much.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank.
John Yearwood is the world editor for the Miami Herald and he joined us from member station WLRN in Miami, Florida.
Dani McClain is a reporter with the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.
And Adrian Walker is a columnist for the Boston Globe.
He joined us from station WBGH in Boston, Massachusetts.
It's time now for our staff song pick of the week, the song ""Saeglopur"" by the band Sigur Ros.
It comes from our intern Shazia Haq.
(Soundbite of song ""Saeglopur"")

Saeglopur."" The song title is Icelandic for lost at sea, but it could stand for meatball lasagna and I wouldn't know the difference, because it's not really about the words or lyrics at all, it's about shutting your eyes, closing the door, and opening your ears.
(Soundbite of song ""Saeglopur"")
I always thought if I ever made it as an Olympic ice skater, this song would win me the gold medal.
Can't you see it?
The toe loop there, the double axle there.
Tara Lipinski standing in the corner.
The camel spin.
Scott Hamilton will be in tears.
The crowd cheers.
Me and my shocking pink sequin leotard with pounds of overdone eye makeup.
I'd bow and thank my good Icelandic friends.
(Soundbite of song ""Saeglopur"")
People always ask, what does the music mean to you?
Well, to me the question is, how do you get through the day when it sucks?
What do you do when you just want to crawl into a ball under your desk on a rainy day with nothing but a bowl of cereal and some Koala Yummies?
How can a single form and its song make you stronger?
(Soundbite of song ""Saeglopur"")
It's a shame to even begin describing it without sounding trite or stale, or drowning into metaphors of glaciers or icebergs or Nordic Fjords.
I first heard the band during my junior in high school.
I was young, dumb, but I knew good music when I heard it.
At the time, my friends and I were working on a deadline for something very serious and very important - the high school yearbook.
With a 30-round clip, you're not defending your home.
You're not hunting deer.
You're hunting people.

Meanwhile, Republican Congressman Peter King of New York announced today he plans to introduce legislation banning anyone from carrying a loaded gun within 1,000 feet of a federal official, from the president down to a member of Congress.
This legislation, I believe is essential.
I believe it's important.
And I always believe if we can take a horrible tragedy and attempt to get something good out of it, then all is not lost.
But opponents of tighter gun laws are not letting down their guard.
Chris Knox of the Firearms Coalition says a law outlawing high-capacity magazines is bound to be ineffective.
Im not that good and I can change a magazine in about a second and a half.
It doesnt take that much you drop the magazine, you put the new one in and you go back.
Anytime you focus on the instrumentality of an act like this, you're focusing your efforts in the wrong place.
Knox says efforts should be focused on preventing people with mental illnesses from obtaining firearms, and that may be one area where gun control opponents and backers can find some common ground.
Brian Naylor, NPR News, Washington.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
When Captain John Smith entered the Chesapeake Bay in the summer of 1608, he found oysters in abundance.
He wrote in his journal: They'd lay as thick as stones.
By the 1800s, watermen were harvesting millions of bushels of oysters every year.
Chesapeake oysters became a delicacy served in the country's finest restaurants.
But the succulent shellfish have been loved almost to extinction.
Overfishing, disease and pollution have left the Chesapeake with only about 1 percent of the oysters it had back then.
Now, scientists and businesspeople are making some headway in bringing them back for the sake of oyster lovers and the bay.
We hear that story from NPR's Elizabeth Shogren.
Marine biologist David Schulte has been trying to engineer a recovery for the bay's oysters - starting with one of its small tributaries.
(Soundbite of anchor setting)
We set anchor over one of the reefs he built on Virginia's Great Wicomico River.
And he sends what looks like a lime-green, canister vacuum cleaner overboard.
It's a remote-controlled submarine.
(Soundbite of motor and splashing)
Schulte's theory was, if you build it and build it big enough, they will come.
And for the past several years, baby oysters have been coming by the millions to his reefs.
Now that, that's a great shot right there.
